verses.text: Do not commit evil, and evil will not overtake you.
verses.comment: Sirach begins with a concise moral principle: avoiding evil protects a person from its consequences. Closely parallels the wisdom tradition found in Proverbs.

verses.text: Stay away from wrongdoing, and it will turn aside from you.
verses.comment: Reinforces personal responsibility in choosing good over evil, a foundational concept in Christian ethics.

verses.text: Do not sow in the furrows of injustice, and you will not reap a double harvest of sin.
verses.comment: The imagery of sowing and reaping sin is a reminder that choices have consequences, a point later echoed by Paul in Galatians 6:7.

verses.text: Do not ask the Lord for authority, or the king for a seat of honor.
verses.comment: A warning against self-promotion. Jesus' teaching about humility at banquets (Luke 14:8-11) echoes this Jewish wisdom.

verses.text: Do not justify yourself before the Lord, and do not display wisdom before the king.
verses.comment: Recognizing humility before God clarifies our true standing, and wisdom among rulers requires discretion.

verses.text: Do not seek to be made a judge, for you might not have enough strength to root out injustice; lest you be swayed by the powerful and compromise your integrity.
verses.comment: Discourages seeking authority for its own sake; presiding over others brings grave responsibilities and accountability.

verses.text: Do not offend the people who sin, or you may be taken captive by your own words.
verses.comment: This verse stresses caution in confronting others, echoing the principle that all have sinned and compassion is needed. See Jesus' approach in John 8:7.

verses.text: Do not commit a second sin, for even for one you will not go unpunished.
verses.comment: This highlights the seriousness of sin and God's justice. Cf. Hebrews' warning about persistent sin after knowledge of truth.

verses.text: Do not say, 'He will consider the great number of my gifts, and when I make my offering to the Most High God, he will accept it.'
verses.comment: Warns against presuming God's favor because of religious practices divorced from sincere repentance.

verses.text: Do not be fainthearted in your prayer, and do not neglect to give alms.
verses.comment: Emphasizes both perseverance in prayer and the importance of almsgiving, which are foundational disciplines for Christian life.

verses.text: Do not ridicule a person who is embittered in spirit, for there is One who humbles and exalts.
verses.comment: God alone has the authority to humble or exalt; empathy with the suffering is a frequent biblical theme.

verses.text: Do not devise a lie against your brother, nor do the same to a friend.
verses.comment: Echoes the commandment against bearing false witness, affirming the need for charity and honesty in all relationships.

verses.text: Do not love to tell any lie, for lying never leads to anything good.
verses.comment: Upholds truthfulness as essential to a righteous life; see Paul's similar exhortation in Colossians 3:9.

verses.text: Do not engage in rambling talk among elders, and do not repeat yourself in your prayer.
verses.comment: Connects to Jesus' teaching against vain repetitions in prayer, encouraging sincerity both in worship and in conversation with leaders.

verses.text: Do not hate hard work, or farm work, which was created by the Most High.
verses.comment: Affirms the dignity and goodness of labor, a foundational teaching drawn from creation itself.

verses.text: Do not join yourself to sinners, but remember that awe of the Lord lasts forever.
verses.comment: Warning against bad company, while pointing to the lasting foundation of living in reverence of God.

verses.text: Do not be slow to humble yourself, nor put off until death the decision to make things right.
verses.comment: Highlights the urgency of repentance and humility, as one does not know the time appointed by God.

verses.text: Do not neglect to honor the dead, and do not overlook the tears of those who mourn.
verses.comment: Calls for acts of mercy and compassion, including the care for the dead and comforting mourners, which have traditionally been considered works of mercy in Christian communities.

verses.text: Do not neglect the weeping of the distressed, but share in the grief of the downtrodden.
verses.comment: Again underscores the importance of sharing burdens, fulfilling the law of Christ (cf. Gal. 6:2).

verses.text: Do not fail to comfort the sorrowful, and do not withhold kindness from the poor.
verses.comment: Acts of corporal and spiritual works of mercy are highlighted as essential to imitation of Christ's love.

verses.text: Do not let the heart of the needy be embittered, nor put off your gift to the poor.
verses.comment: Affirms prompt and cheerful charity as a response to those in need.

verses.text: Do not reject a suppliant in distress, or turn your face away from the poor.
verses.comment: Another reminder that mercy should not be withheld, especially for those in great need.

verses.text: Do not turn away your eyes from the needy, and do not give anyone a reason to curse you.
verses.comment: This reflects the biblical emphasis that someone's prayer or curse can have real consequences; blessing others brings God’s favor.

verses.text: Do not let your hand be stretched out to receive and closed when it is time to give.
verses.comment: Generosity is essential; Jesus echoes this teaching in Luke 6:38.

verses.text: Love your son and discipline him diligently, so that you do not bear his shame.
verses.comment: Discipline and love go hand in hand; the New Testament shows God's parental discipline for our benefit.

verses.text: Give your daughter in marriage and you have accomplished something great, but give her to a man of understanding.
verses.comment: Highlights the importance of godly marriages, emphasizing discernment in choosing a spouse.

verses.text: Honor your father with all your heart, and do not forget the labor of your mother.
verses.comment: The commandment to honor parents is reaffirmed. Honoring parents is a continual, active duty in the Christian life.

verses.text: Remember that you were born of them; how can you repay what they have given you?
verses.comment: Acknowledges the profound debt owed to parents, which echoes New Testament teaching on gratitude and filial piety.

verses.text: Fear the Lord with all your soul, and revere his priests.
verses.comment: Demonstrates the honor due to those who serve God, a principle fulfilled more fully in respecting those entrusted with spiritual leadership in the one holy apostolic church.

verses.text: Love the one who made you with all your strength, and do not neglect his ministers.
verses.comment: Loving God wholeheartedly is united with honoring those he sends, a theme that is deepened in the New Testament teaching on receiving Christ through his representatives.

verses.text: Fear the Lord and honor the priest, and give him his portion, just as you have been commanded: the firstfruits, the guilt offering, the shoulder of the sacrifice, the first fruits of holy things.
verses.comment: Links piety to practical support for God's ministers; foreshadows the idea that the people are called to materially support those devoted full-time to the ministry.

verses.text: Stretch out your hand to the poor, so your blessing may be complete.
verses.comment: Almsgiving leads to blessing—the Old Testament and Jesus both teach that charity is integral to a holy life.

verses.text: Give gladly to all the living, and do not withhold kindness from the dead.
verses.comment: Teaches a spiritual work of mercy: to pray for and honor the dead—a practice attested even in apostolic writings.

verses.text: Do not avoid those who weep, but mourn with the sorrowful.
verses.comment: Sharing in others' grief is an imitation of Christ's compassion and fulfills the law to love one's neighbor.

verses.text: Do not hesitate to visit the sick, for by such deeds you will be loved.
verses.comment: Visiting the sick is a work of mercy praised by Jesus and the apostles; such actions express Christ’s love tangibly.

verses.text: In all your actions, remember your end, and you will never sin.
verses.comment: The call to 'remember your end' refers to meditating on death and final judgment—a powerful spiritual practice for avoiding sin and living rightly before God.
